Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps Sites as an Ecosystem Catalyst

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This is an award to create an Innovation Corps (I-Corps) Site at the University of Delaware (UD) Horn Program in Entrepreneurship. This I-Corps Site will expand this institution's entrepreneurial ecosystem that includes: training opportunities based on lean startup methods; improved physical facilities and service offerings provided by their Venture Development Center; and, an extensive startup support network of engaged entrepreneurs, investors, business service providers, community partners and others. This Site will increase the quantity and velocity of activities aimed at bringing new technologies into the marketplace. The University of Delaware?s Venture Development Center serves as a hatchery/incubator for student startups and will do likewise for I-Corps teams.

This Site is likely to impact the ecosystem of the georgraphical region where this institution is located. In the past, Delaware benefitted from the presence of several large, hi-tech employers But, lingering effects from the economic downturn reduced the state's social and economic wellbeing. Consequently, an increase in startup activity, and the associated creation of new jobs, will serve to improve the economic wellbeing of Delaware and the surrounding region. Broader impacts resulting from participation in the I-Corps Program will also include improved educational outcomes and competitiveness for STEM students, and stronger partnerships between academia and industry. The possibility of receiving funding and joining an I-Corps team may incentivize STEM students to learn about innovation and entrepreneurship by participating in existing training opportunities, thereby improving their educational outcomes and competitiveness. Stronger partnerships between academia and industry will result from interactions between I-Corps team members and prospective industry customers as well as the formation of I-Corps teams that will attempt to commercialize industry technology.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The University of Delaware's (UD's) Horn Entrepreneurship (udel.edu/horn) 2014 proposal was entitled, "I-Corps Site as an Ecosystem Catalyst". In 3+ years post-award, the impacts and outcomes associated with the UD/Horn I-Corps Site have exceeded the high expectations reflected in this title. Specific impacts include: (1) contributing to the establishment of "fostering a spirit of innovation and entrepreneurship" as one of the University's five strategic goals, (2) institutionalizing Lean Launchpad methods as the cornerstone for academic offerings in entrepreneurship, (3) increasing enrollments in entrepreneurship courses by more than 150%, (4) institutionalizing the UD/Horn I-Corps Site program as the lynchpin for the innovative Blue Hen Proof of Concept Program, and (5) expanding resources for supporting entrepreneurship activities by more than 500%, enabling the launch of additional support programs like venture mentoring based in part on MIT's Venture Mentoring Service model.

In terms of direct UD/Horn I-Corps Site outcomes: (1) nineteen cohorts completed the program, (2) each of the 135 teams trained through the Site has been granted an award of up to $3,000 to support customer discovery activities, (3) 21 UD teams - or teams from other institutions that completed the UD I-Corps Site program - have been accepted to the national NSF I-Corps Teams program which provides an additional $50,000 and a 7-week training bootcamp, and (4) more than 20 UD teams received follow on funding, primarily via SBIR/STTR, totaling more than $10.5M.

UD/Horn's I-Corps Site program consists of four, three-hour training sessions that have been continuously refined to guide teams as they seek to complete an initial assessment of commercialization potential through the conduct of customer discovery research. These sessions are supplemented by weekly mentoring sessions and access to startup advising and other supportive resources. In total, 95% of participants who have provided feedback on the UD/Horn I-Corps Site program have rated it as "meeting" or "exceeding" their expectations and 78% have rated it as "very" or "extremely" valuable. In addition, 100% of participants rated the quality of instruction and mentorship as "good" or better. 

Horn Entrepreneurship has successfully leveraged UD?s I-Corps Site program to realize broader impacts. The Site program served as the basis for a 2017 pilot program entitled, "Delaware Startup Launchpad," which offered training sessions and the opportunity to compete for funding awards totaling $5,000 to seven community-based startups. In addition, UD/Horn was awarded an I-Corps supplement, which facilitated a close partnership with Delaware State University (DSU), an HBCU, providing new training opportunities for STEM faculty and students who are underrepresented minorities (URMs). The supplement also enabled UD/Horn to provide support to URM teams from four neighboring Universities - Rowan, Drexel, Temple and Thomas Jefferson.

As noted previously, UD/Horn's I-Corps Site program serves as the lynchpin for an innovative proof of concept model, the Blue Hen Proof of Concept Program (BH-POC), which was shared with the NIN community at the 2017 annual meeting. The model incorporates I-Corps Sites, I-Corps Teams, UD proof of concept funding and SBIR/STTR mechanisms to provide nascent teams with a pathway and support for securing up to $350K in non-dilutive funding. To date, almost $2M has been raised to support the BH-POC via foundation grants and philanthropic gifts and 25 UD teams (100% I-Corps Site graduates) have received awards totaling over $1.2M since its launch less than 3 years ago. Based on the early successes of the BH-POC program, Horn Entrepreneurship won a $50,000 Growth Accelerator Fund Competition from the Small Business Administration (Fall 2019) in order to encourage more UD startups to apply for SBIR/STTR funding.

In summary, the UD/Horn I-Corps Site has served as an effective catalyst for the development of the entrepreneurship ecosystem.

 


Last Modified: 03/02/2020
Modified by: Dan Freeman
